name: Gluggafoss - The Window Waterfall
description: Gluggafoss, translating to "Window Falls" or "Window Waterfall," is one of South Iceland's most geologically fascinating and photogenic cascades, named for the remarkable series of openings—natural "windows"—carved through the soft volcanic rock through which the water flows and can be glimpsed from various angles. Located approximately 117 kilometers from Reykjavík and about 20 kilometers from the village of Hvolsvöllur along Route 261, Gluggafoss presents a unique two-tier structure where the Merkjá river has carved a dramatic channel through a hill composed of different volcanic materials. The upper portion of the waterfall drops 44 meters through a narrow vertical recess cut into soft palagonite (volcanic tuff), while the lower section spreads across a broader basalt ledge and falls an additional 8.5 meters in three main channels, creating a total drop of over 50 meters. The distinctive "windows" that give the waterfall its name formed over thousands of years as the soft palagonite rock eroded unevenly, creating natural tunnels, arches, and openings through which the cascading water can be seen from multiple viewpoints. Historically, the waterfall looked quite different—in 1947, the upper falls were completely hidden, with water flowing through a vertical tunnel behind the cliff and emerging only through the bottom window in a beautiful arch formation.
